title: Kt/V for Dialysis Adequacy
description: Quantifies adequacy of both hemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis treatment using the Daugirdas second-generation equation to assess urea clearance and dialysis effectiveness

parameters.name: pre_dialysis_bun
parameters.description: Pre-dialysis blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level in mg/dL

parameters.name: post_dialysis_bun
parameters.description: Post-dialysis blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level in mg/dL

parameters.name: dialysis_time_hours
parameters.description: Duration of dialysis session in hours

parameters.name: ultrafiltration_volume
parameters.description: Volume of fluid removed during dialysis (ultrafiltration) in liters

parameters.name: post_dialysis_weight
parameters.description: Patient's post-dialysis weight in kilograms (approximates volume of distribution)

parameters.name: dialysis_type
parameters.description: Type of dialysis treatment being assessed

result.name: ktv_adequacy_assessment
result.description: Kt/V calculation with adequacy assessment for dialysis treatment

ranges.interpretation: Dialysis adequacy is inadequate. Consider increasing dialysis time, frequency, or optimizing dialyzer efficiency.
Minimum adequate dialysis for hemodialysis patients. Consider targeting higher Kt/V for optimal outcomes.
Adequate dialysis for hemodialysis patients. Kt/V meets or exceeds KDOQI guidelines target of ≥1.3.
Adequate dialysis meeting ISPD and KDOQI guidelines for peritoneal dialysis patients (≥1.7/week).

references: Daugirdas JT. Second generation logarithmic estimates of single-pool variable volume Kt/V: an analysis of error. J Am Soc Nephrol. 1993 Nov;4(5):1205-13.
National Kidney Foundation. KDOQI Clinical Practice Guidelines for Hemodialysis Adequacy: 2015 update. Am J Kidney Dis. 2015 Nov;66(5):884-930.

Bargman JM, Thorpe KE, Churchill DN; CANUSA Peritoneal Dialysis Study Group. Relative contribution of residual renal function and peritoneal clearance to adequacy of dialysis: a reanalysis of the CANUSA study. J Am Soc Nephrol. 2001 Oct;12(10):2158-62.
Blake PG, Jain AK, Nolph KD. Peritoneal dialysis adequacy: clinical implications. Semin Dial. 2002 Nov-Dec;15(6):411-4.
Locatelli F, Cavalli PL, Tucci B, et al. The effect of different schedules of dialysis on the removal of urea and phosphate. Clin Nephrol. 1999 Feb;51(2):93-102.
formula: Kt/V = -ln(R - 0.008 × t) + (4 - 3.5 × R) × UF/V, where R = Post-BUN/Pre-BUN, t = session time (hours), UF = ultrafiltration volume (L), V = post-dialysis weight (kg)
notes: Based on the Daugirdas second-generation equation for single-pool Kt/V
Validated for Kt/V range between 0.8 and 2.0
Peritoneal dialysis target: Kt/V ≥1.7 per week
Post-dialysis weight approximates volume of distribution (V)
Formula includes correction for urea generation during dialysis
Higher Kt/V values generally associated with better patient outcomes
Should be measured monthly for hemodialysis patients
Kt/V calculation assumes single-pool urea kinetic model
Formula may overestimate Kt/V when values exceed 1.3
